Well,I am a dancer so automatically I liked this film. The only thing I didn't like was they didn't have much dancing as I thought there would be, replacing more dialogue. There were some good fight moves in the film - you have to remember that it is not an action movie, but rather payed homage to classic Hollywood films. Actually what sold me on seeing the movie? Benicio del Toro.
I saw a mediocre MG pilot for Ideas of May 200

I had mixed feelings for "Les Valseuses" (1974) written and directed by Bertrand Blier when I started watching it but I ended up loving it. Some people may disagree with me on this title, saying that the story is way to hateful to be liked and that the characters are too rude, but if you think about it, we have those characters in our mind looking like them with their flaws and all. Grudgingly even being attracted by them

If you are a fan of Zorro, Indiana Jones, or action in general this is a must-see. Directed by Republic's ace team of William Witney and John English and starring John ‘Lucky’ Linderman, Catherine Cooley and one emmy award-winning stuntman from the 60s (Spann Toledo). Hired to face 'The League’, who operate out of Mexico City. After turning a match affected by visible sort damage right into a loser

A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat. The film is based on Stephenie Meyer’s novel of the same name.
